1. Scenario 1

"Given Steve is an avid reader. He is very shy and withdrawing, invariably helpful but he is quite of a introvert with little interest in people or in the world of reality. He has a need for order and structure, and a passion for details". Now when you have got the information about Steve in your mind, I make a question for you if you think he is a Librarian or a Farmer. Most would say he is more likely to be a librarian than a farmer. In mathematical term, it would be something like this: P(Steve is a Librarian∣Steve is an avid reader. He is very shy...)>P(Steve is a Farmer∣Steve is an avid reader. He is very shy...)P(\text{Steve is a Librarian} | \text{Steve is an avid reader. He is very shy...}) > P(\text{Steve is a Farmer} | \text{Steve is an avid reader. He is very shy...})P(Steve is a Librarian∣Steve is an avid reader. He is very shy...)>P(Steve is a Farmer∣Steve is an avid reader. He is very shy...). We write these terms in a more formal way as P(y∣x)P(y|x)P(y∣x) where xxx is a collection of features of Steve and yyy is who he is, Farmer or Librarian.

However, it is not the case.

When saying this, we forget about the fact that the number of Farmer in this world is much more higher than the same figure for Librarian. We have not taken this information into account.

Let me show a drawing representing this case so you would grasp what the actual answer is in an easier and more intuitive way.

As you can see, given the fact we made from the beginning, Steve is more likely to be a Farmer rather than a Librarian.

Now come back to our topic, discriminative and generative models. How different are they from each other?

  • P(y|x) : given features of x, find a transformation from x space to y space.
  • P(x|y) : given y, find a transformation that mapping from y to distribution of x.
  • P(y|x) = P(x|y)*P(y)/P(x), knowing P(x|y) then we calculate P(x, y) because P(x|y=a) may have a high value but P(y=a) really small.
